title: Skewness and Kurtosis: Understanding Distribution Shape
contentHtml:
In descriptive statistics, skewness and kurtosis are two fundamental measures of a distribution's shape.

Skewness measures how asymmetrical the distribution is, while kurtosis measures its 'tailed-ness' or 'peaked-ness'. Understanding these properties is crucial in many fields, including machine learning and artificial intelligence.

subject: statistics
title: Shape of Distributions: Skewness and Kurtosis
contentHtml: Understanding the shape of a distribution is crucial in descriptive statistics. In this card, we'll explore skewness and kurtosis, two fundamental measures that help us describe the asymmetry and heaviness of distributions.

workedExample.problemHtml: Consider the exam scores of a class with mean 80 and standard deviation 10. If the distribution is skewed to the right, what can we infer about the scores?

steps.explanation: If the distribution is skewed to the right, it means that more students scored above the mean.

workedExample.finalAnswer: The scores are likely clustered towards the higher end.

intuition: Skewness measures how asymmetrical a distribution is. A positive skewness indicates a tail-heavy distribution, while a negative skewness suggests a tail-light distribution.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, understanding the shape of distributions can help in selecting appropriate algorithms and preprocessing techniques.
